title: 28 Execute a Command on One or More Consecutive Lines
description:
Many Ex commands can be given a [range] of lines to act upon. We can specify the start and end of a range with either a line number, a mark, or a pattern.
  • . symbol represents the current line.
  • $ symbol represents the end of the buffer.
  • % symbol stands for all the lines in the current file.

title: 29 Duplicate or Move Lines Using `:t` and `:m` Commands.
description:
The :copy command (and its shorthand :t) lets us duplicate one or more lines from one part of the document to another, while the :move command lets us place them somewhere else in the document.

title: 30 Run Normal Mode Commands Across a Range
description: If we want to run a Normal mode command on a series of consecutive lines, we can do so using the :normal command. When used in combination with the dot command or a macro, we can perform repetitive tasks with very little effort.
